As the Secretary-General of the United Nations from 2007 to 2016, Ban Ki-moon approached human rights violations in conflict zones through a multi-faceted approach that included advocacy, diplomacy, and the mobilization of UN resources.

Firstly, Ban Ki-moon publicly and repeatedly condemned human rights abuses and violations of international humanitarian law in conflict zones, calling on all parties to the conflict to respect human rights and protect civilians. He used his platform as the Secretary-General to bring attention to specific cases, such as the use of chemical weapons in Syria and the targeting of civilians by all sides of the conflict in Yemen.

Secondly, Ban Ki-moon engaged in diplomatic efforts to resolve conflicts and prevent further human rights abuses. He supported the efforts of UN mediators, worked with regional organizations such as the African Union and the Arab League, and joined other diplomatic initiatives to end conflicts, such as the negotiations that led to the Iran nuclear deal.

Thirdly, Ban Ki-moon used UN resources to promote human rights and strengthen protections for civilians in conflict zones. This included deploying peacekeeping missions to protect civilians and promote human rights in places such as South Sudan and the Central African Republic, as well as providing humanitarian aid to people affected by conflicts.

Overall, Ban Ki-moon's approach to human rights violations in conflict zones was characterized by a combination of public advocacy, diplomatic engagement, and UN resources to promote human rights and protect civilians in the context of conflicts.
